conditions for the staff are pretty
demoralizing."

Carey Thomas Feminist Alliance.

tenured faculty at Hopkins. As
recently as 1985, only eight of
305 professors here were women.

coming here has changed these
figures somewhat."

of North Carolina (MCNC) is

study areas related to
microelectronics at five North
Carolina universities, according

MCNC.

With each and every breath
you take, you go deeper and

relaxed.
With these words hypnotist

audience, as everyone else in

mouths gaping open. All the
while, eerie music washed over
their ears. The only other thing
one could hear was the hypnotist's voice. Were the
volunteers actually falling into a
trance, or were they just play-

acting?

world's fastest hypnotist, had the
volunteers under the control of
his voice in seconds. One person
went from being a child on a
merry-go-round one moment to
being Elvis Presley the next moment, giving an unrehearsed performance of"Love Me Tender"
to the wild applause of the audience. "Poof! Sleep," said
Kolisch, and the person he had
awakened fell back into deep
sleep.

and all of the hypnotist's suggestions, responded so spontaneously to Kolisch's voice as to almost
exclude the possibility that they
were feigning hypnosis. No matter how often the audience burst
into laughter or interrupted with

A Minor Point
A long overdue proposal will be put forward to the Committee on Undergraduate
Studies after Thanksgiving, one which has
the potential to open up and diversify
Hopkins undergraduate education. The proposal, being submitted by Jeff DeCagna,
a member of the CUS, is to expand the
number of departments which offer minors.
Presently, many of the language departments, Art History and Writing Seminars
have programs for a minor.
The minor, by indicating concentrated
study in an additional field, is recognition
for efforts to expand the scope of education. It can supplement or complement the
major, displaying either interest and
knowledge in a broader range of subjects
or enhanced understanding of a field of
study through interdepartmental approach.
Naturally, a more well-rounded education should be sought, regardless of notations on a transcript. It would be a mistake,
however, for Hopkins not to encourage expanding a student's horizons by offering
some acknowledgement.
Writing Seminars offers evidence that instituting a minor encourages participation
in a department. Four years ago, Writing
Sems decided to go ahead with a minor.
The requirements were set at one half of
those for the Writing Sems major. The institution of a minor enabled students outside of the department to take Writing Sems
courses, for in the minor program was
stipulated that minors as well as majors get
first crack at the courses before the rest of

the student body. Demand was overwhelming. The minor was removed for a year.
Though it was reinstituted under the condition that students going for the minor
would have to compete with the rest of the
school for courses, Writing Seminars continues to attract great numbers of students.
The department's insightfulness into the
mentality of Hopkins students is admirable.
Also, while encouraging many more
students to actively participate in the program, the department is thriving.
Perhaps it is a secondary point, but
minors also encourage a broader education
by making it easier to do so. Students are
enticed to double major largely to satisfy
their own interests, but also to show that
they have tried to broaden themselves
(although the recognition of a notation on
one's transcript is, in this regard, unsatisfactory). The attempt to double major
is a great strain—and so potentially
detrimental to an undergraduate career. Offering minors gives the opportunity to
relieve some of the pressure, since there are
fewer requirements.
While the proposal includes recommendations which bear close scrutiny, the inherent logic of the minor should push it to
approval. The proposal calls for institution
of the minor's programs as of September,
1988. Given prudent execution by the CUS,
and subsequently by the Programs Committees of the academic departments, there is
no reason not to implement minors at that
time.

The members of the Faculty-Student interaction committee meeting to discuss future plans.

Each semester students and
their professors are given the
chance to informally interact at
baseball games, museums and
even in the wilderness. These
meetings are all part of the Faculty/Student Interaction Program
coordinated by the Office of the
Dean of Students.
The program originated when
a similar program at Columbia
University was brought to the attention of Dean of Students Chris
Colombo. The first session at
Hopkins was then held during the
Spring of 1985.
According to Director of Student Activities Susan Boswell, the
program was established "to give
students the chance to find out
about the faculty's interests in a
social setting as opposed to an
academic setting. Also, it was to
give the faculty a chance to get to

know students outside of the
classroom."
The program usually consists
of fifteen events per semester.
These events are based upon the
suggestions of the Faculty/Student Interaction Committee or are
sometimes conceived by the professors themselves. Professors
become involved in the program
through the recommendations of
other professors and students.
The response from students has
been positive from the begining.
Boswell says, "There is usually
a waiting list, and by the first day
50 students have signed up."
Also, faculty interest has increased with the addition of more
faculty to the committee. The
committee is currently chaired by
Special Assistant to the Dean
Mary Ellen Porter.
One particularly event this
semester was the visit to Professor of Materials Science and
Engineering Robert Pond's farm

in Carroll County. Students first
attended the Carroll County Farm
Museum's Fall Harvest Day and
then were given a tour of the
Pond farm. Junior Fred Andres
recalls,"He showed us his amazing home made entirely of cement. It was built to withstand a
Mack Truck's driving across the
second floor." He also was impressed by the "hand-dug tunnels
that connected Pond's two
workshops and organ chamber to
the house." Andres believes that
the afternoon definitely gave him
the opportunity to meet Pond
informally.
Other popular activities have
been "High Tea" at Bertha's in
Fells Point and the Charm City
Comedy Club.
Next semester's Faculty/Student Interaction is now in the process of being put together and will
include opening day baseball at
Memorial Stadium and "High
Tea" at Bertha's.

Barnstormers' Fantasticks not so fantastic
by Brooke A. Ettle
The Barnstormer's production
of The Fantasticks this past
weekend was not what one would
expect from a typical musical.
There was no overly-obnoxious
tap dancing, no specticular
lighting effects or technical
wizardry. Director Jonathan
Tycko, acknowledging these
shortcomings in his program
notes, asked his audience to
"abandon [their] preconceptions
about the art of musical theater
and love." His intentions were
honorable, but Tycko fell
somewhat short of his goal of
conveying the "essence of theater
and love." While Fantasticks
delivered many swashbuckling
and stunning moments, its pace
was oftentimes too slow to engage
its audience.
Fantasticks possessed all the
elements of an endearing love
story. Matt (Michael Robinson),
a young college boy, and his sixteen year old neighhbor Luisa
(Jill Austin) fall in love despite a
wall erected by their parents between
the
two
houses.
Unbeknownst to the children, the
parents, Hucklebee (Kara Stein)
and Bellomy (Sanjay Aggarwal),
built the wall intending that the
two fall in love and eventually
marry. "To

A Minor Point
A long overdue proposal will be put forward to the Committee on Undergraduate
Studies after Thanksgiving, one which has
the potential to open up and diversify
Hopkins undergraduate education. The proposal, being submitted by Jeff DeCagna,
a member of the CUS, is to expand the
number of departments which offer minors.
Presently, many of the language departments, Art History and Writing Seminars
have programs for a minor.
The minor, by indicating concentrated
study in an additional field, is recognition
for efforts to expand the scope of education. It can supplement or complement the
major, displaying either interest and
knowledge in a broader range of subjects
or enhanced understanding of a field of
study through interdepartmental approach.
Naturally, a more well-rounded education should be sought, regardless of notations on a transcript. It would be a mistake,
however, for Hopkins not to encourage expanding a student's horizons by offering
some acknowledgement.
Writing Seminars offers evidence that instituting a minor encourages participation
in a department. Four years ago, Writing
Sems decided to go ahead with a minor.
The requirements were set at one half of
those for the Writing Sems major. The institution of a minor enabled students outside of the department to take Writing Sems
courses, for in the minor program was
stipulated that minors as well as majors get
first crack at the courses before the rest of

the student body. Demand was overwhelming. The minor was removed for a year.
Though it was reinstituted under the condition that students going for the minor
would have to compete with the rest of the
school for courses, Writing Seminars continues to attract great numbers of students.
The department's insightfulness into the
mentality of Hopkins students is admirable.
Also, while encouraging many more
students to actively participate in the program, the department is thriving.
Perhaps it is a secondary point, but
minors also encourage a broader education
by making it easier to do so. Students are
enticed to double major largely to satisfy
their own interests, but also to show that
they have tried to broaden themselves
(although the recognition of a notation on
one's transcript is, in this regard, unsatisfactory). The attempt to double major
is a great strain—and so potentially
detrimental to an undergraduate career. Offering minors gives the opportunity to
relieve some of the pressure, since there are
fewer requirements.
While the proposal includes recommendations which bear close scrutiny, the inherent logic of the minor should push it to
approval. The proposal calls for institution
of the minor's programs as of September,
1988. Given prudent execution by the CUS,
and subsequently by the Programs Committees of the academic departments, there is
no reason not to implement minors at that
time.

a similar program at Columbia

Colombo. The first session at
Hopkins was then held during the
Spring of 1985.
According to Director of Student Activities Susan Boswell, the
program was established "to give
students the chance to find out
about the faculty's interests in a
social setting as opposed to an
academic setting. Also, it was to
give the faculty a chance to get to

know students outside of the
classroom."
The program usually consists
of fifteen events per semester.
These events are based upon the
suggestions of the Faculty/Student Interaction Committee or are
sometimes conceived by the professors themselves. Professors
become involved in the program
through the recommendations of
other professors and students.
The response from students has
been positive from the begining.
Boswell says, "There is usually
a waiting list, and by the first day
50 students have signed up."

committee is currently chaired by

become

does not spend the rest of the
novel hunting her down. (Don't
let the blurb on the back cover

understand love and war and survival. Love in this novel is not

beach; yes, David thinks he loves

high tech f,i-ces into a region

ason, their lives governed by
